quote: You cannot spend money in luxury without doing good to the poor. Nay, you do more good to them by spending it in luxury, than by giving it; for by spending it in luxury, you make them exert industry, whereas by giving it, you keep them idle.
A man will turn over half a library to make one book.
That we must all die, we always knew; I wish I had remembered it sooner.
In order that all men may be taught to speak the truth, it is necessary that all likewise should learn to hear it.
There are few things that we so unwillingly give up, even in advanced age, as the supposition that we still have the power of ingratiating ourselves with the fair sex.
There are few ways in which a man can be more innocently employed than in getting money.
There is, indeed, nothing that so much seduces reason from vigilance, as the thought of passing life with an amiable woman.
Worth seeing? Yes; but not worth going to see.
A man who has not been in Italy, is always conscious of an inferiority.
